courses.subject: BASA
courses.title: Research Methodology in Behavioural Studies I
courses.description: This course is divided into two main parts. The first part is focused on the application of the philosophy of science to behavioral research in business. Basic concepts such as explanation, scientific laws, and theory are introduced and discussed. The second part provides an introduction to the various stages of scientific research which include research design, measurement scale and development, sampling design, data collection and statistical analysis. Even though mathematical proofs and statistical derivations will be reduced to a minimum, having the knowledge of basic statistics and matrix manipulations will be helpful.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Management; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
courses.learning_outcomes:
After finishing this course, it is expected that students should:
- Be able to understand and comment on the appropriateness of various methodologies used in survey research
- Be able to select an appropriate research design independently for their own research
- Be able to learn new methodologies in the future independently based on what they have learned in this course
courses.required_readings:
1. Kerlinger, F.N. & Lee, H.B. (2000) Foundations of behavioral research. Fourth Edition, Belmont CA:Cengage Learning.
2. Hair, J.F., Anderson, R.E., Tatham, R.L., & Black, W.C. (1998). Multivariate data analysis. Fifth Edition, New Jersey: Prentice Hall.
3. Johnson, R.A., & Wichern, D.W. (1982). Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis. NJ:Prentice Hall Inc.
4. Neter, J., Kutner, M.H., Nachtsheim, C.J. & Wasserman, W. (1996). Applied linear statistical models. Chicago:Irwin.
5. Bollen, K.A. (1989). Structural Equations with Latent Variables. NY:John Wiley & Sons.
6. Bryk, A.S. & Raudenbush, S.W. (1992). Hierarchical linear models – Applications and data analysis methods. Newbury Park:Sage Publications.
7. Hedges, L.V. & Olkin, I (1985). Statistical methods for meta-analysis. San Diego:Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Publishers.
8. Nunnally, J.C., & Bernstein, I.H. (1994). Psychometric theory. NY:McGraw-Hill Series in Psychology.
9. Pedhazur, E.J. (1983). Multiple regression in behavioral research – Explanation and prediction. NY:Holt, Rinehart & Winston.
10. Cohen, J. & Cohen, P. (1983). Applied multiple regression/correlation analysis for the behavioral sciences. NJ:Erlbaum.Loehlin, J.C. (1992). Latent variable models: An introduction to factor, path, and structural analysis. NJ:Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Publishers.
11. SAGE University series: Quantitative Applications in the Social Sciences
12. Green, S.B., Salkind, N.J., & Akey, T.M. (2000). Using SPSS for Windows – Analyzing and understanding data. NJ:Prentice Hall.

courses.subject: BASA
courses.title: Research Methodology in Behavioural Studies II
courses.description: This course is the continuation of BASA6001. The course covers concepts and techniques related to behavioral experiment. In particular, students will learn how to apply various types of behavioral research design and statistical methods, and how to analyze and interpret the results. Sample topics include among others experimental design, significance tests , statistical power, interaction and moderating effects, testing of psychological mechanism. This course does not involve mathematical proofs or statistical derivations. Good knowledge of basic statistics is essential. Prerequisite: BASA6001
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Management; or MPhil-PhD Marketing; Prerequisite: BASA6001
courses.learning_outcomes:
Course Outcomes
1. Knowledge of major experimental approaches for studying human behaviors.
2. Techniques in analyzing data collected from experiments.
3. Hands-on experience in experimental design, administration, data analysis, and report writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Characteristics of Experimental Approach

2. Critical Elements of an Experiment (I) – Manipulation

3. Critical Elements of an Experiment (II) – Control techniques

4. Experimental validity, power, replicability, and data collection

5. Hypothesis Testing and Statistical Power Computation

- One-Factor Design, One-way ANOVA, and Multiple-comparison Testing

- Alternative view and problems of NHST

- Power and predetermine sample size

6. Factorial Design 1: Data analysis with ANOVA techniques

- Factorial analysis of variance

- How to explicate interaction pattern

7. Factorial Design 2: Data analysis with Regression (Spotlights, Floodlights) techniques

- Spotlights and Floodlights

8. Within-Subject Design: Repeated Measures Analysis with ANOVA and Regression techniques

- Repeated measures ANOVA

- Regression

9. Ways to study psychological processes and its corresponding data analysis procedures

10. Conducting single-paper meta-analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are welcome to express their comments and suggestions via the following formal and

informal feedback channels:

* Course teaching evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
* E-mail. Feel free to send comments to the instructor via e-mail.
courses.required_readings:
#### References and Books on Design

Shadish, W. R. , Cook, T. D., & Campbell, D. T. (2002). *Experimental and quasi-experimental designs for generalized causal inference*. CA: Wadsworth/Cengage Learning.

Christensen L. B. (2007). *Experimental methodology*. 10th Edition. Allyn and Bacon.

Tutorials in consumer research. *Journal of Consumer Research.* https://academic.oup.com/jcr/pages/tutorials

Reis, H. T., & Judd, C. M. (2014). *Handbook of research methods in social and personality psychology*, 2nd Edition. NY: Cambridge University Press.

#### References on Statistical Analysis

Howell, D. C. (2013). *Statistical methods for psychology*. 8th Edition. CA: Duxbury Press.

Keppel, G., & Wickens, T. D. (2004). *Design and analysis: A researcher’s handbook*, 4th Edition. NJ: Pearson.
courses.recommended_readings:
Trochim, W. M. *The Research Methods Knowledge Base*, 2nd Edition. Online version available at Web Center For Social Research Methods <<http://www.socialresearchmethods.net/kb/>> (version current as of October 20, 2006).

* *Resources on writing and citation style**

<http://www.apastyle.org/learn/tutorials/basics-tutorial.aspx> (The Basics of APA Style Online Tutorial) Note: Download their free sample APA papers from the end of their tutorial.

Other journal articles would be recommended throughout the course.
